Her monthly income varies between 6.000,00MT and 7.000,00MT (U$140 to U$160). With this money she supports her family and tries to save some to improve her living conditions. She is asking for a U$525 loan in order to buy aluminum pots, as there's demand for those and she thinks it'll improve her profits.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of aluminum pots

loans.name: Dupe

texts.en: Dupe is 25 years old and married with one child. She has a business center where she photocopies documents for her customers. She is requesting for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase an additional photocopier. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a photocopier

loans.name: Fahima Bene Hesar Group

texts.en:
Fahima is the group leader of Fahima Bene Hesar Group which is made up of five female members. Each of them would like to expand their business and bring some new changes to it.

Fahima would like to take a loan for her tailoring business. She has been a tailor for more than ten years. With the money she wants to buy a new sewing machine to sew good-quality clothes.

Sediqa wants to take a loan to buy fresh fruit to sell in the market.

Nargis wants to take a loan for her quilt-sewing business.

Husnia wants to take a loan for her bakery shop to buy flour and firewood.

Rahima wants to take a loan to buy new kinds of cosmetics for her beauty salon that is located in her house.

Together, they have requested a group loan of 50,000 Afghani.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Narciso Pedro

texts.pt:
Narciso Pedro V. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, capital de Moçambique, tem 30 anos de idade pai de 4 filhos de 3 a 9 anos de idade destes os mais velhos vão à escola. Vive na casa própria em Massaca, distrito de Boane com a sua família e um irmão. Neste momento frequenta o 3º ano de faculdade de ciências pedagógicas na Universidade Pedagógica em Maputo, sua esposa também trabalha como educadora num infantário.

Sempre viveu com os seus pais na cidade de Maputo ate ao seu casamento onde decidiu fixar sua residência em Massaca. Trabalha como docente a mais de 10 anos, foi formado pelo Instituto do Magistério Primário da Matola (IMAP) neste momento aufere um salário de 7.000.00MT por mês. Tem uma empregada domestica e por vezes consegue poupar cerca de 2.000.00MT por mês.

Já pediu empréstimo no Banco comercial BIM no valor de 29.000.00MT para o inicio da sua obra, é através de seus amigos que também são clientes que conheceu a Hluvuku depois de sua analise, preferiu continuar a levantar créditos nesta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 25.000.00MT com o qual pretende comprar portas, cimento, pedra, areia e outros. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 15.000.00MT, 20.000.00MT e 35.000.00MT todos para a mesma actividade.

No futuro gostaria de pedir mais empréstimos para a conclusão da sua residência e adquirir uma viatura, como forma de dar mais conforte e comodidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Narciso Pedro V. was born in the city of Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. He is 30 years old and the father of 4 children, ages 3 to 9. The older children attend school. He lives in a home he owns in Massaca, in the Boane district, with his family and a brother. He is in his third year in the teaching program at the Teacher's University in Maputo. His wife also works as a preschool teacher. He lived with his parents in the city of Maputo until he got married, when he decided to move to Massaca. He has worked as a teacher for more than 10 years. He graduated from the Institute of Elementary Education of Matola (IMAP). He currently earns a monthly salary of 7.000.00 MT. He has a maid, and sometimes is able to save around 2.000.00MT per month. Narciso had already requested a loan from the BIM commercial bank for the amount of 29.000.00MT to begin construction on his home. He learned about Hluvuku through friends who are clients and after an analysis, decided to take out loans through Hluvuku. This 25.000.000MT loan is his third with Hluvuku, and will be used to purchase doors, cement, stones, sand, etc. The previous loans were for 15.000.00MT, 20.000.00MT and 35.000.00MT, all for the same purpose. In the future, he would like to take out more loans to complete his home and to purchase a car, as a way to provide more comfort and convenience to his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, stones, etc. )

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina M. is in the business of selling rice, beans, and eggs at a restaurant.  She is requesting a loan to purchase larger saucepans.  With the extra profits she receives from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy chickens, beef etc to cook in the restaurant.

Regina is 40 years old and is married to a soldier. She has 3 children who all go to school.  

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bigger sauspans

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes D. is a hair dresser. Agnes owns her own beauty salon where she sells hair products such as hair creams, wigs and wiveons in addition to doing hair dressing. Her beauty salon is located in Abotoase. Agnes has been selling is a hairdresser and sells hair products such as hair creams, wigs and wiveons since 2006.



Agnes has received schooling through junior high. She is married with 2 children. She is responsible for paying school fees and feeding the children.



Her loan will be used to buy other assorted cosmetics and hair products for use at her salon. With the new profit from her expanded business, Agnes plans to save for the future!

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy other assorted cosmetics and hair products for use at her salon.

loans.name: Arnaldo

texts.pt:
Arnaldo Tivane nasceu no Distrito de Boane na Província de Maputo, tem 31 anos de idade, é Viúvo pai de 2 filhos de 08 e 05 anos de idade, o primeiro vai à escola. Estudou ate 10ªclasse, parou de estudar devido à natureza do seu trabalho, pois era obrigado a madrugar e voltava sempre tarde. Vive na casa cedida pelos pais e para alem dos filhos sustenta também 06 irmãos que vivem com ele. 

Nunca mudou da residência, nasceu e cresceu em Boane, casou-se 2008 e mais tarde a esposa faleceu.
É negociante a tempo permanente a mais de 05 anos e faz em media 10 horas diárias e não tem empregado, aprendeu a fazer o negocio em Boane por iniciativa própria, tem essa experiência há 06 anos, seu rendimento mensal varia de 5.000,00MT a 6.000,00MT com o qual sustenta a família e poupa através de um esquema tradicional entre amigos. 

Nunca levantou créditos em outras instituições financeiras e este é o seu terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000,00MT com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (areia, pedra, cimento, ferro e outros) para concluir a sua obra. Os seus empréstimos anteriores foram de 7.500,00MT e 17.000,00MT ambos para o melhoramento da habitação. Conheceu a Hluvuku graças a amigos que também são clientes da instituição.
Fez o pagamento dos dois primeiros empréstimos sem problemas e compromete-se a continuar a pagar bem para poder aceder a outros créditos para reabilitar a palhota dos pais e comprar uma camioneta para o escoamento da sua mercadoria.
texts.en:
Arnaldo Tivane was born in Boane, in the district of Maputo. He is 31, a widow and father of two sons ages 8 and 5, the older one goes to school. He studied until 10th grade but had to drop school because of the nature of his job, that forced him to work late at night. He lives in a house given to him by his parents, and besides his children he also supports 6 brothers that live with him. He's never changed addresses, was born and raised in Boane, got married in 2008 and lost his wife recently. He's been a full time salesman for the past 5 years, working around 10 hours a day and has no employees. He makes between 5.000,00MT and 6.000,00MT (U$ 170 to U$200) per month, which he uses to support his family and save some. He's asking for a 20.000,00MT (U$700) loan, which he'll use to buy construction supplies (sand, rocks, cement, iron and others) in order to finish building his house. He hasn't have a problem paying back past loans and plans on paying this one quickly so he can make some more, hoping to buy a truck to help with his business in the future.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construction supplies (sand, rock, cement, others)

loans.name: Ayobami

texts.en: Ayobami sells foodstuff  in front of her house. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State and has been in the business for the past 20 years.  She is 48 years old and married with 2 children. She is requesting for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more foodstuff to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuff to sell

loans.name: Mare

texts.en:
Mare C. is in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking materials like flour, cooking oil etc. 

Mare is 31 years old and is married to a soldier. She has 6 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a restaurant at the nearby market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more baking materials like flour, cooking oil etc

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan runs a small cafeteria in the central marketplace of his home town of Vinogradovo. It’s a small town in Western Ukraine. There are few nice places to eat that combine good food and pleasant environment. Ivan’s cafeteria is an affordable café where one can always expect a decent meal at a reasonable price. Ivan has been working in the sphere of catering for 10 years. Presently, he has 40,000 Grivnyas in working capital. His income amounts to 6,000 Grivnyas a month.  

Ivan is seeking a loan of 12,000 Grivnyas to purchase new quality tables for his cafeteria. He wants to create a nice and welcoming atmosphere in his café to attract new potential customers. One of Ivan’s big dreams is to open a pizza place some day.

loans.use: to purchase new cafeteria tables

loans.name: Williams

texts.en: Williams A. is married and has three children. He has received schooling through junior high. Williams is a woodworker who does carpentry, joinery and other construction work at Kwamikrom. He has done this since 2001. Williams is single-handedly responsible for all the financial expenses of his family. Williams will use the loan to purchase more seasoned wood to work with. With the new profits from his expanded business, Williams plans to reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase more of the seasoned wood

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en: Godwin A. sells Agro Chemicals in Abotoase. Godwin has not received any formal education.  He is married and has six dependants. His wife is a trader. Godwin has been selling Agro Chemicals for the past five years. He is responsible for footing the financial needs of the children and the entire family.  With the high demand for Agro Chemicals for the lean farming season, Godwin will use the loan to buy more of the agro chemicals for sale to the farmers. He hopes to save the new profit from his expanded business.

loans.use: To buy more of the agro chemicals to sell

loans.name: Olayemi

texts.en: Olayemi sells shoes and has been in the business for the past 13 years. She uses part of her profit for the family upkeep. She is 42 years old and married with three children.  She hopes for a loan of N40,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 43 years old and married with three children. She sells vegetables to make a living. She sells her vegetables in the mornings to her clients to enable them eat the vegetables fresh. She is requesting a loan of N60,000 to purchase more vegetables to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya is married. She runs a small business selling household items and footwear in one of the local markets in Dneprorudnyi. She has been in this business for eight years. Currently, she has about 20,000 Grivnyas in merchandise.  

Lidiya is requesting a 10,000 Grivnya loan to increase her assortment of merchandise. She always aims at high quality and wants to have all her clients pleased with the results of her work. Lidiya is a very determined and focused entrepreneur. She has repaid 20 loans without any problems. Lidiya invests her profit in her kids' education.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan J. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase firewood and yeasts for brewing.  Susan is 30 years old and married to a soldier. She has six children, who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar and purchase crates of beer to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase firewood and yeast for brewing

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married and has two grown kids. She is an entrepreneur from Pavlograd.

Ludmila sells children’s clothing and footwear in the central marketplace of her home town and has been in this trade for three years. Presently, her turnover amounts to 50,000 Grivnyas and her net profit is about 5,500-7,500 Grivnyas a month. 

Ludmila is seeking a loan of 8,200 Grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise, i.e. jackets, jumpers and assorted footwear for children. She wants to stock her kiosk with good quality inventory that will sell well and bring her a good income

Ludmila seeks to keep her business running and thriving as it’s the only source of income for her family. She believes this loan will be very beneficial for further growth of her enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine K. sells fresh fish in Abotoase. She is married and has four dependents. Her husband is a trader. Justine did not receive any form of formal education.

Justine has been selling fresh fish for ten years and helps her husband to pay the housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to be processed for sale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to be processed for sale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen sells dried fish. She purchases fresh fish from the market and dries it at home to sell. She is 39 years old and married with four children.

Helen is hoping for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more fresh fish to dry and sell to her customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to be dried for sale

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke sells plastic items in the market and has been in the business for the past ten years. She is 42 years old and married with two children.

Funke hopes for the loan of N40,000 to purchase more plastic items to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more plastic items to sell

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is 39 years old and married with four children. She sells medicines and has been in this business for the past three years. She uses part of her profit for the family upkeep.

Adenike hopes for the loan of N40,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders for their help.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married with three children. She is an entrepreneur from Kamenka who runs a small business selling food items in the local market. Svetlana sells groceries, tea, coffee and fruit. She owns a nice big vending kiosk with good quality refrigerated coolers and a wide selection of groceries for sale. She has been in this business for ten years. Currently, Svetlana has about 60,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her net profit amounts to 7,000-8,000 Grivnyas a month.

At present, Svetlana is requesting a loan of 16,685 Grivnyas to purchase fresh fruit which always sells well in the cold season. Svetlana has promptly repaid nine previous loans without any delinquencies which characterizes her as a responsible client capable of current loan repayment. One of Svetlana’s long-term plans is to open her own little grocery store. She has already purchased land for construction work on it.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fruit.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. sells fresh fish in Abotoase. Comfort has received basic education.  She is married and has four dependants. Her husband is a trader. She is responsible for paying the children's school fees and the household utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish from fishermen for sale and the remains will be processed and preserved by way of smoking the fish for the market. She hopes to save the new profits from her business.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish for sale and the remains will be processed and preserved by way of smoking the fish for the market..

loans.name: Younish

texts.en:
Younish P. currently sells cooking oil, salt, sugar, etc. at a shop and is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell. Younish is 40 years-old and is married with a husband that is a farmer. She has eight children and they go to school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a restaurant.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Tobereh

texts.en: Tobereh sells poultry birds. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to be able to meet the requirements of her clients. She is 38 years-old and married with six children. She is hoping for a loan of  NGN 150,000 in order to purchase more poultry. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry to sell.

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is married with two children. She runs a small business in the Central market of Melitopol. She sells yarn and knitting supplies which is a unique type of merchandise. There are few other persons working in this sphere of trade. Yelena has been in this business for over eleven years and she has a great deal of experience. Her enterprise has benefited from lending assistance. Currently, she has about 30,000 Grivnyas in stock. Her net profit amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas a month.

Yelena is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas in order to increase her working capital. She is a true entrepreneur – enterprising, decisive and determined. She is striving to make a better life for her family. We believe Yelena’s natural talent to adequately assess the current environment and take advantage of it will stimulate her business to grow and keep it sustainable and profitable helping Yelena achieve independence and security in life.

loans.use: To increase working capital.

loans.name: Jose Antonio

texts.pt:
José António M. nasceu no bairro Chinonankila, distrito de Boane na província de Maputo, tem 28 anos de idade é casado sem filhos. Fez 7ª classe, e não foi possível continuar devido à falta de condições financeiras por parte dos seus pais. Vive com a sua esposa e mensalmente tem enviado algum valor para o sustento da mãe.

Saiu de Boane para Suazilândia em 1990 a fim de arranjar emprego e continuar com os estudos, aprendeu a trabalhar na oficina de reparação de viaturas como bate chapa, e regressa a Boane para abrir uma oficina própria em 1999. Actualmente trabalha com um ajudante e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00MT por mês, poupa algum no Banco Barclays.

Nunca pediu empréstimos em outras instituições bancárias, conheceu a Hluvuku através da dona Júlia que também é cliente desta instituição a longa data. Este é o seu 2º credito do Jose no valor de 15.000.00MT com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, areia e outros). O empréstimo anterior foi de 12.500.00MT para a mesma actividade.

Um dos seus objectivos é de concluir a sua obra para dar melhores condições de acomodação a sua família, no futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimo para a construção de uma mercearia e iniciar uma actividade comercial.

José António M. nasceu no bairro Chinonankila, distrito de Boane na província de Maputo, tem 28 anos de idade é casado sem filhos. Fez 7ª classe, e não foi possível continuar devido à falta de condições financeiras por parte dos seus pais. Vive com a sua esposa e mensalmente tem enviado algum valor para o sustento da mãe.

Saiu de Boane para Suazilândia em 1990 a fim de arranjar emprego e continuar com os estudos, aprendeu a trabalhar na oficina de reparação de viaturas como bate chapa, e regressa a Boane para abrir uma oficina própria em 1999. Actualmente trabalha com um ajudante e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00MT por mês, poupa algum no Banco Barclays.

Nunca pediu empréstimos em outras instituições bancárias, conheceu a Hluvuku através da dona Júlia que também é cliente desta instituição a longa data. Este é o seu 2º credito do Jose no valor de 15.000.00MT com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, areia e outros). O empréstimo anterior foi de 12.500.00MT para a mesma actividade.

Um dos seus objectivos é de concluir a sua obra para dar melhores condições de acomodação a sua família, no futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimo para a construção de uma mercearia e iniciar uma actividade comercial.
texts.en:
José António M. was born in the neighborhood of Chinonakila, district of Boane, Maputo province in Mozambique. He is 28 years old, married and has no children. He finished 7th grade but had to drop school because of his parent's lack of financial conditions. He lives with his wife and and sends money to support his mother every month. He opened his own car repair shop in 1999, but now he works as an assistant and makes around 6.000,00MT (U$200) per month, being able to save a little bit every month at the Barclays Bank. This is Jose's second loan and he's asking for 15.000,00MT (U$ 525) in order to buy construction supplies (cement, rocks and others). His previous loan was for 12.500,00MT (U$ 450) for the same purpose, and he paid it back with no problems. He hopes to finish building his house so he can give his wife and mother a better life, and dreams of opening his own business in the future.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construction supplies (sand, rock, cement, others)

loans.name: Zinaida

texts.en:
Zinaida is married with a grown daughter. She lives and runs her small business in Zaporozhye.

Zinaida sells children’s clothing in one of the biggest local markets and owns two vending locations in the same marketplace. She can boast a wide assortment of inventory, flexible pricing policy and loyal clientele. She started this business fifteen years ago. Presently, it has grown to 70,000 Grivnyas in turnover and 5,000 Grivnyas in monthly net profit.

Zinaida is seeking a loan of 12,100 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal clothing for further retail sales in her kiosks. She hopes this loan will help her expand and boost her sales.

We believe Zinaida’s natural ability to think through what is most essential, and to make quick and wise decisions, will help her succeed and repay the current loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal children's clothing

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 45 years old and married with four children aged 10 through 16 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she lives with six people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Esther rears chickens at her home in Lugala and so doesn’t pay rent because she works from her home. She sells in the outskirts of Kampala and has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for three years.

Esther buys feed for her chickens from Owino market and so incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation and the ever-increasing price of feed. Esther wants to use this loan to buy more bags of feed.

Esther aspires to seeing her business grow stronger and to own 1,000 chickens.

loans.use: To buy more bags of feed for her chickens

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba C. is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. She is 47 years old and is married to a soldier. She has seven children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Abose

texts.en: Abose sells bags and shoes in an open-air market. She has been in the business for the past 15 years. She is 42 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo Stata.   She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more bags and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Olubola

texts.en: Olubola sells medicine and has been in the business for the past 8 years. She  is 45 years old  and married with 4 children.  She is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She say thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith G. sells fish in Abotoase. Edith has received schooling through senior high.  She is single and has no dependents. Edith has been selling fish for 5 years. She is solely responsible for her personal needs as well as the payment of all her bills. Her loan will be used to buy the fish in large quantity for resale. She hopes to reinvest the new profit from her expanded business.

loans.use: to buy fish in large quantity for resale

loans.name: Osahon

texts.en: Osahon is 48 years old and married with 3 children. She sells various kinds of shoes. She is requesting the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Jose

texts.pt:
José F. nasceu na cidade de Tete, Província de mesmo nome no centro de Moçambique, tem 56 anos de idade, casado e pai de 1 filho de 26 anos de idade. Fez 3ª classe e não foi possível continuar porque foi solicitado para cumprir com o serviço militar obrigatório. Vive na casa própria com a sua família. Para além desta, sustenta também sua mãe que está em Tete enviando dinheiro mensalmente. 

Em 1974 saiu de Tete para Tanzânia como combatente, volta directamente para o quartel de Boane Província de Maputo e foi desmobilizado em 1995, convida a sua família para juntos residirem em Boane. Actualmente é desmobilizado e pensionista. Faz agricultura com a sua esposa e faz em media cerca de 10 a 11 horas de trabalho por dia, aprendeu esta actividade em Tanzânia quando foi incorporado como militar em 1975. 

Recebe uma pensão do Ministério da Defesa no valor de 2.900.00MT por mês e, com ajuda do rendimento da machamba, consegue sustentar a família e ainda poupar algum no Banco BARCLAYS.

Nunca pediu empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu vizinho e amigos. Este é o seu 3º credito no valor de 12.000.00MT, com o qual pretende comprar chapas de zinco, ferro, cimento e outros. Os anteriores empréstimos foram de 8.000.00MT e 10.300.00MT, ambos foram pagos sem problemas e para a mesma actividade. 

Neste empréstimo tem como objectivo, concluir a sua obra e melhorar as condições sanitárias. Pretende pedir mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e compra de mobiliário de casa.
texts.en:
José F. was born in Tete, in central Mozambique. He is 56, married and has a 26 year old son. He finished 3rd grade but had to drop school to join the army. He lives in his own house with his famliy. He also supports his mother in Tete, sending her money every month. In 1974, Jose left Tete to Tanzania with the army; he later came back to Boane and retired from the army in 1995. He gets a monthly pension of 2.900,00MT (U$ 100) per month from the military. He and his wife are farm workers and work between 10 and 11 hours every day. This is Jose's third loan in the amount of 12.000,00MT (U$425) which he'sll use to buy construction supplies (zinc, iron, cement, and others) in order to finish building his house and improve the sanitary conditions. He hopes to pay this loan without a problem so he can ask for another one in order to buy furniture.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construction supplies (sand, rock, cement, others)

loans.name: Celeste

texts.pt:
Celeste M. nasceu em Namaacha, distrito fronteiriço com a Suazilândia, tem 52 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 8 filhos. Não conhece a idade dos filhos, mas os mais novos e com idade escolar estão estudando. Não foi a escola, os pais na altura deram prioridade ao trabalho agrícola. Vive na casa própria com a família e sustenta mais 4 netos enviando géneros alimentícios mensalmente.

Saiu de Namaacha para Maputo devido à guerra de desestabilização em 1985, após a guerra decidiu fixar a sua residência e viver com a sua família em Mahanhane no Distrito de Boane. 

Neste momento é operaria permanente numa empresa agrícola de produção e venda de banana (Bananalandia) a mais de sete anos, esta actividade aprendeu na mesma empresa já a mais de 9 anos. Tem um salário mensal de 1.630.00mt, alem deste consegue um rendimento de cerca de 2.000.00mt da venda de produtos da sua machamba. Depois das despesas consegue poupar um pouco através do sistema de poupança tradicional (Xitique). 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outras instituições, conheceu a Hluvuku numa reunião da empresa realizada pelo Sr. Joaquim João. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo nesta instituição no valor de 10.000.00MT com qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, pedra e outros) para iniciar a sua obra. 
Celeste compromete se apagar conforme o plano de reembolso para poder aceder a mais créditos ate concretizar o seu objectivo, que é ter uma casa condigna.
texts.en:
Celeste M. was born in Namaacha, a frontier distric to Suazilândia. She is 52 years old, widow, and mother of 8 children. She doesn’t know her children’s ages but the younger are studying. She hasn’t gone to school, since for her parents the agricultural work took priority. She lives in her own house with her family, and also supports four grandchildren by monthly sending them food. She left Namaacha to Maputo due to the 1985 Destabilization War in 1985. After War she decided to fix residency and live with her family in Mahanhane, in the distric of Boane. She has been a permanent worker for more than 7 years at an agricultural company that produces and sells bananas (Bananalandia) . She learned this activity more than 9 years ago. Her monthly salary is MZN 1,630.00. In addition to that, she earns about MZN 2,000.00 by selling produce from her vegetable garden. After expenses she is able to save a little through the traditional system Xitique. She has never gotten loans from other institutions. She learned about Hluvuku in a meeting at her company, organized by Mr. Joaquim João. This is her first loan with this institution, in the amount of MZN 10,000.00. With this loan, she intends to buy construction materials (cement, sand, stones and others) to start a construction. Celeste is committed to repay according to the reimbursement plan in order to reach more loan, until she can achieve her goal to have a house worthy of respect.

Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials (cement, blocks and others)

loans.name: Omoriyeba

texts.en: Omoriyeba is 60 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State.  She sells firewood in front of her house and has been in the business for the past 17 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more firewood to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan is 30 years old and married with four children. All her children go to school .She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she is staying with six people. Chan takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Chan owns a stall selling cabbages and yellow bananas and doesn’t pay rent because she works from her home. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for two years. Chan buys cabbages and yellow bananas from Nakawa market and so incurs little transport cost to and from shopping.

Her challenges include transportation of ripe yellow bananas and the ever increasing price of food. Chan wants to use this loan to buy more cabbages and clusters of yellow bananas. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow stronger and owning a stall in Nakawa market, the very place where she does her shopping.

loans.use: to buy more clusters of  yellow bananas and cabbages  for resale

loans.name: Vincentia

texts.en: Vincentia K. is a fish monger who also sells smoked fish in Abotoase. Vincentia has received basic education.  She is married and has 4 dependents.  Vincentia has been smoking fish and selling smoked fish for 15 years. She helps her husband in paying the housekeeping expenses and feeding the children. Her loan will be used to buy fresh fish from other fishermen, to be smoked for sale. She hopes to reinvest the new profit from her expanded business.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish to smoke for resale

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade is 35 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State where she sell medicine and has been in the business for the past 16 years. With the profit she makes from the business, she takes care of her family. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Safina

texts.en:
Safina is 29 years old, married with two children, aged 9 and 11 years. Both her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she is staying with four people. Safina takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Safina owns a retail shop selling day-to-day essentials and doesn’t pay rent because she works from her home. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for two years.

Safina buys merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation of merchandise and the ever increasing price of goods. Safina wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her retail shop..She is aspiring of seeing her business grow stronger and owning a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her retail shop

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin  sells sarongs in front of her house and has been in the business for the past 8 years. She is 38 years old and married with 3 children.   She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State and she has been with LAPO for years. She is requesting the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Régina  Olga Ahouefa

texts.fr: A. Régina  Olga Ahouefa est née en 1974 à Porto-Novo, capitale politique du Bénin. Régina  Olga Ahouefa réside au quartier Djassin à Porto-Novo depuis cinq ans. Mariée à ABOYA Bruno, Régina  Olga Ahouefa est mère de deux enfants dont un est scolarisé. Régina  Olga Ahouefa vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Ayant abandonné les classes au secondaire, Régina  Olga Ahouefa a commencé depuis six ans la vente de maïs, du charbon de bois, de fagots de bois et de divers à son domicile. Régina  Olga Ahouefa s’approvisionne à Dangbo et à Avrankou, deux villages situés à proximité de Porto-Novo. Régina  Olga Ahouefa a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé à ALIDé. Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et la diversifier par l'achat d'autres produits,  Régina  Olga Ahouefa sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Régina Olga Ahouefa A. was born in 1974 in Porto-Novo, the political capital of Bénin. Régina Olga Ahouefa has lived in Porto-Novo's Djassin neighborhood for five years. Régina Olga Ahouefa is married to Bruno Aboya and is the mother of two children, one of whom is in school. Régina Olga Ahouefa lives with her husband and her children. The couple meets the family's expenses together. Having dropped out of school in high school, six years ago Régina Olga Ahouefa began selling corn, wood coal, bundles of firewood and miscellaneous items out of her home. Régina Olga Ahouefa gets her supplies in Dangbo and in Avrankou, two towns situated near Porto-Novo. Régina Olga Ahouefa has already benefited from one loan that she repaid correctly to Alidé. Régina Olga Ahouefa is requesting a second loan from Alidé in order to increase the size of her business and to diversify by purchasing other products.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase miscellaneous items, corn, fabric and jewelry

loans.name: Muji

texts.en:
Muji is 35 years old and married with five children. She sells shoes and has been in the business for the past ten years. She uses part of her profit for the family upkeep.

Muji hopes for the loan of N40,000 to purchase more shoes to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis A. is married and has four dependents. He has received schooling through junior high.

Francis is fisherman in Abotoase, which he has done for ten years. His wife is a fishmonger. Francis uses his income to pay the children’s school fees and to pay utility bills.

Francis will use the loan to purchase fishing equipment such as a net and a larger boat to go fishing with. With the new profits from his expanded business, he plans to reinvest.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment such as a net and a larger boat

loans.name: Sandra Cristina

texts.pt:
Sandra Cristina M. nasceu na Matola, província de Maputo, tem 36 anos de idade, viúva e sem filhos, estudou ate 12 classe, parou de estudar por falta de condições para ingressar no ensino superior, tem ajudado seus pais enviando algum dinheiro mensalmente.

Em 1994 saiu da casa dos seus pais na Matola para o seu lar na cidade de Maputo onde actualmente vive sozinha depois de ter perdido o seu marido.

Ė Comerciante ambulante e dona do negócio a 09 anos por iniciativa própria logo depois da perda do marido no ano 2000. Compra os produtos na Africa do Sul e vende a grosso para outros comerciantes. O rendimento mensal varia de 4.000,00mt a 5.000,00mt com o qual sustenta a família e consegue poupar algum para investir na sua obra.

Nunca trabalhou com nenhuma outra instituição financeira e este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 12.000,00mt, com o qual pretende comprar bebidas alcoólicas e carnes para revender. Conheceu a instituição graças a um amigo seu que também é cliente da mesma. 

Compromete-se a pagar bem o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros financiamentos para concluir a sua obra e introduzir água canalizada.
texts.en:
Sandra Cristina M. was born in Matola, province of Maputo. She is 36 years old, widow, and has no children. She studied up to the 12th grade. She stopped her studies because she didn’t have conditions to enter university. She has helped her parents by monthly sending them some money.

In 1994 she left her parents’ house in Matola to her home in Maputo, where she currently lives by herself since she lost her husband. She is an itinerant trader and owns her business for 9 years, from her own initiative, right after she lost her husband, in 2000.

She buys products in South Africa and sells in the wholesale to other retailers. Her monthly earnings vary from MZN 4,000 to MZN 5,000, with which she supports her family and is able to save something to invest in her construction.

She has never worked with another financial institution and this is her first loan, in the amount of MZN 12,000. With this value, she intends to buy alcoholic beverages and meet to resell.

She learned about this institution from a friend who is also one of its clients. She is committed to repay well the loan in order to reach new ones so that she can conclude her construction and install running water.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and selling of beverages and meet

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 23 years old and is single. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with four people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Margaret owns a retail shop selling dresses and dressmaking materials in Makerere-Kikoni, in the outskirts of Kampala, and doesn’t pay business rent because, she works from her home. She buys her merchandise from Kiyembe shops in Kampala and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. Her challenges include transportation of merchandise and the ever-increasing prices of clothes.

Margaret has been in this business for one year and with MCDT for two years and is servicing her third loan. Margaret wants to use this loan to buy more dressmaking materials. She aspires to seeing her business grow stronger and to owning a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more dressmaking materials

loans.name: Belinda

texts.pt:
Belinda M. nasceu em Magude (distrito localizado no norte da província de Maputo), tem 51 nos de idade, viúva e mãe de 03 filhos todos maiores de idade e já casados. Estudou ate 4 classe parou de estudar quando foi ao lar. Para alem dos filhos sustenta uma sobrinha que vive com ela.

Saiu de Magude com seu marido quando este foi transferido pelos serviços para trabalhar na cidade de Maputo.
Ė Comerciante permanente a mais de 05 anos e faz 08 horas diárias, trabalha pessoalmente não tem nenhum empregado. Aprendeu a fazer o negócio por iniciativa própria logo depois de perder o seu marido, o seu rendimento vária de 6.000,00mt a 7.000,00mt com o qual sustenta a família e consegue poupar algum para investir no seu negócio e no melhoramento da sua qualidade de vida. 

Nunca trabalhou com nenhuma outra instituição de crédito e este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na HLUVUKU-ADSEMA, no valor de 10.000,00mt com o qual pretende aumentar a mercadoria para responder a procura que é cada vez crescente e consequentemente o seu rendimento. Vende refrigerantes, bebidas e outros produtos. 

Conheceu a HLUVUKU-ADSEMA graças a um vizinho que também é cliente da instituição. Compromete-se a pagar bem o empréstimo para poder aceder a outros financiamentos para ligar agua e mobilar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Belinda M. was born in Magude (district located in the north of the province of Maputo). She is 51 years old, widow, and mother of three children, all of them adults and married. She studied up to the 4th grade and stopped when she became a housewife. Besides her children, she supports a niece who lives with her.

She left Magude with her husband when he was transferred at his work to Maputo. She has been a retailer for more than 5 years, and works 8 hours a day. She works by herself and has no employees. She learned to do business by herself after she lost her husband. Her earnings vary from MZN 6,000 to MZN 7,000, with which she supports her family and saves some money to invest in her business, as well in improving her living quality.

She has never worked with another credit institution and this is her first loan from Hluvuku-Adsema, of MZN 10,000. With this loan, she intends to increase her inventory to meet the increasing demand, and consequently raise her earnings. She sells sodas, beverages and other products.

She learned about Hluvuku-Adsema thanks to a neighbor, who is also one of the institution’s clients. She commits to repay well the loan in order to reach new ones so that she can have running water and furnish her house.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and selling of products

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel S. is married and has 5 dependents. He has received schooling through high school. Samuel is a photographer and owns a small photo studio in Abotoase.  He also sells electrical appliances, which he has done for 7 years. His wife is a petty trader. Samuel uses his income to pay for financial responsibilities. Samuel will use the loan to purchase components for cameras, film, and other accessories to enhance his photography work, and also to add to his capital to purchase some electrical appliances to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Samuel plans to reinvent.

loans.use: To purchase cameras parts and accessories and electrical appliances

loans.name: Sameira Group

texts.en: Sameira is the leader of this Group, which has three members. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses. Sameira and Mah Jan want a loan to buy necessary materials for their tailoring businesses. Gull Tab wants to take a loan for her general store.  The members say that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Stella Kaimuri

texts.en: Stella Kaimuri K. owns the Lucky Barber Shop, which provides haircuts and styling as well as photocopying.  She has four employees in the shop, and deals with challenges such as power outages.   She will use the loan of KES 50,000 to buy a blowdryer and paper supplies for printing.  Stella is married with four children and describes herself as hardworking, honest and visionary. She wants to open five branches of her shop in areas like Rongai, Towncentre and Parklands.

loans.use: To buy a blowdryer and additional paper stock

loans.name: Hellen Abalem

texts.en: Hellen Abalem L. sells clothes in a stall in a retail market in downtown Thika.  Her offerings focus on bed linens and baby clothes; she has done this for 10 years and has one employee.  She is using her KES 50,000 loan proceeds to increase her inventory. One challenge her business faced is that her kiosk had to be taken down due to a city counsel ruling and she has had to relocate. Hellen is married to a mechanic who has his own shop and they have two children ages 6 and 11. Hellen describes herself as a hardworking, honest businesswoman, and her goal is to have branches of her clothes stall in three nearby villages.

loans.use: To increase stock of sheets, bed covers and baby clothes

loans.name: Jenneth

texts.en:
This is Jenneth M., 36 years old, who lives and does business in Baseco, Port Area, Manila. She is married to Jose, 63, a vendor like her. One of their two children goes to grade school.

Jenneth has been doing business for three years. She buys and sells assorted vegetables. Currently, she concentrates on onions and tomatoes. She has a stall in a nearby flea market. Jenneth earns a net income of P10,000 a month, although she says sales go down on rainy days.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2004. Jenneth is now on her 11th loan. She is expecting a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of P18,000 as additional capital. With this fresh capital, she can purchase more assorted vegetables from traders for her business.

She hopes to have a larger vegetable stall soon.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions and has been in the business for the past 15 years. She uses part of her profit for the family upkeep and invests the rest in her business.  She hopes for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is married and has 4 dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Agnes sells maize and charcoal in bags in Kwamikrom, which she has done for 7 years. Her husband is a businessman. Agnes uses her income in taking care of the children’s food and payment of fees for the children.

Agnes will use the loan to purchase charcoal and additional grains such as millet and beans for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to reinvest.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal and grains such as millet, and beans for resale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria E., 53 years old. She lives and does business in Tala, Caloocan City. Gloria recounts that she met with an accident when she was in college which rendered her disabled.

Her disability has never been a hindrance for her in facing life’s challenges. Now, she’s earning at least P13,000 a month from selling vegetables, spices, and newspapers. She’s been in business for ten years now.

Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, she has found and kept more friends in the community. She has found new meaning to her life. Now on her 13th loan, Gloria expects a new loan in the amount of P22,000 to add to her business capital.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Akouavi Victorine

texts.fr: A. Akouavi Victorine est née en 1967 à Adja au centre du Bénin. Akouavi Victorine vit depuis six ans à Louho, un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale politique du Bénin. Mariée à SAGBOHAN Ambroise, un enseignant, Akouavi Victorine a six enfants en charge, tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Les charges de la famille sont supportées à la fois par Akouavi Victorine et son conjoint Ambroise. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Akouavi Victorine a commencé depuis son bas âge la vente de divers (maïs, riz, farine de manioc, etc.) à son domicile. Akouavi Victorine fait ses emplettes à Pobè, à proximité de Porto-Novo. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour accroître la taille de son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle afin de réaliser plus d'économies, Akouavi Victorine sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Akouavi Victorine Ameghihoue was born in 1967 at Adja in central Benin. Akouavi Victorine has lived for the last 6 years in Louho, a suburb of Porto-Nova, the capital of Benin. She is married to Ambroise Sagbohan a student and cares for six children who have all attended school with three having children of their own. The family expenses are met by Akouavi and her partner Ambroise. Having never attended school, Akouavi Victorine started at an early age to sell assorted products (corn, rice, manioc flour etc) from her home. Akouavi buys her supplies in Pobe near Porto-Novo. She is a old client of ALIde and has already made two loans which have been duly repaid. To increase the size of her business and satisfy the needs of her clients by becoming more competitive, Akouavi Victorine is requesting this third loan from ALIde.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted products (rice, corn, manioc flour)

loans.name: Enyonam

texts.en:
Enyonam A. sells cloth and footwear in Kwamikrom. Enyonam has received junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a businessman.

Enyonam has been selling cloth and footwear for the past 5 years. She is responsible for paying the children’s school fees, and helping her husband in paying the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more of the cloth and footwear for resale. She plans to reinvest the new profit from her expanded business.

loans.use: to buy more of the cloth and footwear for resale

loans.name: Shahna Group

texts.en: Shahna is the leader of Shahna group. All three members of this group would like to borrow money for their businesses, requesting a group loan of 56000 Afghani. Shahna wants to take a loan for her embroidery business, while  Sabara desires a loan for her general store.  Faryba wants to take a loan for her fruit-selling business. They are very happy these loans are available in Afghanistan, and they thank all lenders of Kiva and AFSG.

loans.use: Business expansion.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena V. and her family live in Silang, Cavite, a breezy town in the southern part of Metro Manila. She is 42 years old. Her husband Arnulfo is a businessman. They have four children, two of whom are in school.

Lorena has been managing her own small bakery and general store for ten years now. She employs the services of a neighbor as assistant. She earns at least P6,000 a month. She uses her profits to support the education of her children, especially the one in college. She was also able to have their car fixed thru her earnings/savings.

She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P10,000 to purchase raw materials for bread production (flour, sugar, and lard). This is her 12th loan with the cooperative.

Lorena’s utmost dream is to see all her children obtain their college degree.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for bread making

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: B. Antoinette est née en 1963 et vit depuis cinq ans à Louho, un quartier de Porto-Novo, capitale politique du Bénin. Antoinette est mariée à HOUNNOU Casimir, un enseignant, et est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont quatre sont à sa charge. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Antoinette  a abandonné l’école au cours primaire et s’est mise depuis vingt cinq ans à vendre des divers (conserves, savons, lait, sucre, insecticides, galette d’arachide, etc.) ainsi que de l’huile végétale à son domicile. Antoinette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Antoinette  est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a antérieurement bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés à ALIDé. En vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de satisfaire sa clientèle, Antoinette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Antoinette B. was born in 1963 and has lived for five years in Louho, a neighborhood of Porto Novo, political capital of Benin. Antoinette is married to Casimir Hounnou, a teacher, and is the mother of five children who all attend school, four of whom are in her care. The couple share the family expenses. Antoinette left primary school and has dedicated herself for twenty-five years to selling various provisions (canned goods, soap, milk, sugar, insecticides, groundnut cookies, etc.) as well as vegetable oil from her residence. Antoinette purchases her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Antoinette is a former customer of ALIDé that earlier benefitted from two loans, which she repaid well to ALIDé. In order to increase her working capital and better satisfy her clientele, Antoinette requests a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various provisions (soap, sardines, tomato in cans, milk, sugar packages) and alcohol.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. processes and manufactures local soap called ‘Azumah blows’ in Kwamikrom. This soap is made of dried cocoa pods and dried plantain peels, burnt, and the ashes boiled with water to get the base for the soap.

Mary has received junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Mary has been selling this local soap since 2007. She is responsible for taking care of the children’s clothing and food expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more of the ingredients to manufacture and then sell the soap in large quantity. With the new profit from Mary's expanded business, she plans to save.

loans.use: to buy more of the ingredients to manufacture soap

loans.name: Annalyn

texts.en:
Direct selling is a tried and tested alternative source of income for many Filipino housewives, and Annalyn G., 27 years old, is one of them.  She lives with her family in Silang, Cavite.  Annalyn is married to Joel, 26, a maintenance worker.
 
Annalyn started with her direct selling of cosmetics and apparel only last year.  She did this to augment the meager income from the operation of their motorized tricycle.  She now earns close to P14,000 a month, especially during peak months nearing the Christmas season.  From her profits, she was able to purchase a brand new washing machine for the family and she was able to renovate their kitchen sink.  

In 2007, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She is applying for a loan in the amount of P12,000 so she can purchase more items to sell.  

She is working hard to help her husband cover their basic daily needs.  She dreams of seeing her family living in their own house and on their own lot soon.  She dreams of having her own service center for cosmetics and apparel.  She also hopes to acquire a car for the family.

      

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Precila P., 34, is a store owner from Silang, Cavite. She lives with her husband, Rolly, who works for a construction firm.

Precila manages a general store, although she started selling ornamental plants years back. Her general store is now two years old. She earns at least 15,000 PHP a month. She invests her profits in her general store and ornamental plants businesses for their continuous growth.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year, but it has already been providing her the necessary assistance she needs for the continuity of her business. Precila applied for a new loan amounting to 9,000 PHP as additional capital for her store and nursery. Precila said she has been praying for a baby.

Yolanda A., 52, is a preacher’s wife. Her three children are in college, high school, and grade school, respectively. Her family lives in Camarin, Caloocan City.

Yolanda has been buying and selling ready-made curtains for walls, windows, and doors for four years. She earns 2,000 PHP a month. She uses her profits to send her children to school.

This would be her 12th loan cycle. She will use some of the profits for her children’s education. She works hard to carry them through college.

Yolanda fervently prays for more customers and additional business ventures.

He wants to use the loan to buy more inventory for the general store and to add used items for resale. He was introduced to KADET by a friend. He has never borrowed from an MFI before. He hopes to expand his business by filling the general store and adding secondhand goods. He has ventured into the designing of school uniforms for primary school children, and he hopes to get a business in this after the models are accepted by schools.

loans.name: Francisco Fredy

texts.es:
El señor Francisco de 48 años  se dedica a la produccion de leche junto con su esposa la señora margarita ellos tienen 10 años de matrimonio, ellos viven en maica central  en una vivienda muy humilde ninguno de los dos pudo terminar  la escuela  son personas trabajadoras que desde las  cuatro de la mañana se dedican a hordeñar  las vacas y despues a cortar alfa para la alimentacion de las mismas. Y al mismo tiempo el señor Francisco se dedica a la construccion (albañil) por mas de 15 años.Apesar que sus ingresos como albañil no son muy buenos alcanza para pagar la alimentacion de la familia.

Ellos tienen cinco hijos pequeños de los cuales 3 van a la escuela de la zona.Ambos el señor Francisco como su esposa trabajan mucho para poderles dar una vida mejor y hacer a que sus hijos tengan una buena educacion. Con el credito solicitado ellos podran comprar una vaca y aumentar su entrega de leche y poder mejorar la casita en la que viven y establecer un mejor nivel de vida para su familia y en especial para sus niños.
texts.en:
Sr. Francisco is 48 years old and produces milk together with his wife Sra. Margarita. They have been married for 10 years and they live in Central Maica in a very humble home. Neither of the two could finish school. They are hard-working people. From 4 o´clock in the morning, they milk the cows and afterwards they cut alfalfa for the cow´s food. At the same time, Sr. Francisco also has been in construction (builder) for more than 15 years. Due to the fact that his income as a builder is not very good, they must reach to pay for the family´s food.

They have 5 little children, of whom 3 go to school in the area. Both Sr. Francisco as well as his wife work a lot so that they can give them a better life, and make sure that their children have a good education. With the requested loan, they will be able to buy a cow and increase its milk delivery, so that they can improve the little house that they live in and establish a better level of life for the family and especially for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

texts.en:
Malolet M. is a 32-year-old general store owner who lives in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. Rizalino, her husband, is a carpenter.  Their only child is in grade school.

Malolet owns and manages a general store, which has been in existence for eight years now. She also sells fresh meat at her store. Additionally, she provides water services to a few neighbors. Combined, she makes 50,000 PHP a month. Malolet says perennial rains and flooding hinder the growth of her store but thanks to her perseverance, she will get through it.

In 2004, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She has seen a lot of economic, as well as spiritual, developments in her life since joining the cooperative.  She has learned from the cooperative the importance of saving for the future. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of 26,000 PHP as additional capital for the growth of her store. She will re-stock her grocery inventory. She hopes to see her store grow even bigger.

texts.en:
Rose G. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through the basic education level. Rose sells fish and “white clay” in Kwamikrom, which she has done since 1999. The “white clay” is a particular clay type in a part of the Volta Region in the Republic of Ghana, which is burnt in a very hot oven and eaten as something of one's choice. 

Rose uses her income to pay for payment of the children’s school fees and other housekeeping expenses. Rose will use the loan to buy more of the clay for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rose plans to reinvest.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha G. is a 57-year-old entrepreneur. Her husband, Miguel, 59, drives for a living. Together with their three children, they live in a populous urban community in Dasmarinas, Cavite.

Editha has been a successful distributor of health products, which she obtains from a reputable distribution chain. She is also engaged in direct-selling of cosmetics and apparels. She has been enjoying her business for four years now. Although she sometimes find it difficult to collect debts on earlier purchase orders of her clients, she still enjoys doing her business because she goes everywhere and meets a lot of people. With her business, she earns 18,000 PHP a month.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. She is now  applying for a new loan in the amount of 30,000 PHP to infuse more capital into her business.  he is also saving most of her profits so she can soon buy her dream car. She wishes to also establish her own outlet for her health products so she won’t need to leave every time.

loans.name: Nurbubu's Group

texts.ru:
Нурбубу – лидер этой группы. Нурбубу мать пятерых детей. Самому старшему уже тридцать один год, а самой младшей дочке всего лишь девять лет. Нурбубу и её муж – фермеры с многолетним стажем. Они разводят мелко – рогатый скот в специализированных сараях для содержания скота, известных под названием «кашар». Их кашар находится в пригороде Балыкчы. Нурбубу счастлива, что вырастила столько детей. Ведь все они теперь активно помогают своим родителям и вносят тем самым свой вклад в семейный бизнес. Начали же они с того, что держали скот у себя дома. За короткое время им удалось увеличить поголовье и им потребовалось более крупное помещение, которое они удачно нашли. Скотоводство стало золотой нишей для Нурбубу, так как благодаря этому роду деятельности Нурбубу и её муж значительно повысили свой жизненный уровень. Во-первых, они без особых трудностей женили сына, справили свадьбу и в придачу купили ему машину. Все расходы были покрыты за счёт проданной скотины. Ей пятьдесят два года, но даже сейчас она усердно трудится изо дня в день и вкладывает всю душу для того, чтобы их хозяйство процветало. Их изначальный вклад составлял около пятнадцати тысяч сомов. Теперь же, они зарабатывают треть этой суммы за один месяц.  
Нурбубу решила обратиться за кредитом с целью закупить корм на зиму. Это позволило бы успешно откармливать скот до весны. Нурбубу очень хочет выкупить кашар в течение двух лет. Для этого она готова приложить все усилия. 

Партнёры Нурбубу по группе: Абдыкадыр, Айгуль, Берметкан и Анара

Абдыкадыру пятьдесят шесть. Женат, отец двоих детей. Чтобы прокормить семью Абдыкадыр занимается разведением мелкого рогатого скота в кашаре. Абдыкадыру нужен кредит для того, чтобы заготовить корм на зиму. 

Айгуль сорок восемь. Она мать двоих детей. Айгуль – домохозяйка. Муж занимается перевозкой и продажей угля. А также 15 дней в месяц работает водителем на стекло – заводе. Айгуль нужен кредит, чтобы оплатить контракт дочери в ВУЗе. 

Берметкан сорок девять. У неё одна единственная дочь. Берметкан разводит мелкий рогатый скота, а её муж работает на стройке. С помощью кредита, Берметкан собирается закупить корм для скотины на зиму.

Анаре сорок. Четыре года назад Анара решила занятся коммерцией. Она начала продавать жевательные резинки, семечки, орехи и табачные изделия. Муж уже вовлечён в её бизнес. Анаре нужен кредит для увеличения товарооборота. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Nurbubu is a leader of this group. She is a mother of five children. Her oldest son is now 31 years old and youngest daughter is only nine. Nurbubu and her husband are farmers. They breed small cattle in specialized sheds for keeping cattle which are known as "kashars." Their kashar is in the suburb of Balykchi. Nurbubu is happy that she has grown so many children. Because all of them are actively helping their parents and by that contribute to their family business. They started with just keeping the cattle at their home. In a short period of time they managed to increase the headcount of cattle and they soon need a large space which they successfully found. Animal husbandry has become a golden niche for Nurbubu because thanks to this business Nurbubu and her husband have significantly improved their quality of life. Firstly, they have married their son without any difficulties, celebrated his wedding and bought him a car. All the expenses were covered by the profit made from selling cattle. Nurbubu is fifty two years old, but even now she works very hard every day and gives her soul to the growth of their business. Their starting capital included around fifteen thousand soms. Right now they can already make the third of this amount in one month. Nurbubu has decided to ask for a loan with the purpose to buy fodder for the winter time. This will allow her to successfully feed the cattle until the spring. Nurbubu very much wants to pay off the kashar in the next two years. She is ready to do everything she can to achieve it. Nurbubu's group partners are: Abdykadyr, Aigul, Bermetkan and Anara. Abdykadyr is sixty six years old. He is married and is a father of two children. To feed the family he breeds small cattle in the kashar. Abdykadyr needs a loan to prepare the fodder for the winter. Aigul is forty eight years old. She is a mother of two children. Aigul is a housewife. Her husband transports and sells coal. He also works as a driver on the glass factory every fifteen days. Aigul needs a loan to pay her daughter's college tuition. Bermetkan is forty nine years old. She is has an only daughter. Bermetkan breeds small cattle and her husband works in construction. With the help of the loan Bermetkan plans to buy fodder for the cattle for the winter. Anara is forty years old. Four years ago Anara decided to start a business. She started selling gum, seeds, nuts and tobacco products. Her husband is already involved in her business. Anara needs a loan to increase her circulation of merchandise. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fodder for cattle for winter time

loans.name: Busirat

texts.en: Busirat sells food very close to her house. She has been in business for the past five years. She is 37 years old and married with two children. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more food to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders for your support.
